This is a purely categorical result, and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The result is of interest to the foundations of quantum theory, and to the reconstruction of quantum theory from a more fundamental theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and a less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to a minimal structure, which is similar to the stinging structures in cnidarians. In addition, we find that myxozoans have one of the smallest reported animal genomes. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of the host immune system to control viral infections is a key factor in the survival of the host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the IFN antagonism mechanism of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to combat this pandemic. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of global crop yields. Here, we quantify the magnitude of this increase in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of LMH in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet in the study of LMH ecology and conservation. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to the selective removal of the smaller particles by a combination of processes yet to be discovered. This finding has important implications for the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Interstellar grains are the only direct evidence of the origin of the elements. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also found that a minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We conclude that the grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium and that the bulk of the cosmogenic nuclides were acquired in the interstellar medium. Furthermore, we found that the grains were exposed to a particle flux of the early active sun that was lower than the present-day flux. This indicates that the early solar system was not as active as it is today.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most difficult to increase. We show that the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power, not by the availability of resources. This is a major finding because it suggests that the most important factor limiting the reproductive output of mammals is the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is the most toxic form of the protein. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying treatment for this orphan disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor the pandemic and inform policy decisions. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the data that are available are often not in a common format. We present the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This infrastructure will enable researchers to use the data to monitor the pandemic and to inform policy decisions. We hope that the infrastructure will also be useful to the public health community.

This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change over time. The gut microbiome is also susceptible to changes in the host diet, which can lead to changes in the composition of the microbiome. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products. These natural products could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high probability of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats. We identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is mimicked by pharmacological inhibition of the mitochondrial respiratory chain in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases that can be digitally synthesized. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the developing human fetus and is down-regulated in the adult. We also show that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of many effective therapies, the survival of many cancer patients remains poor. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, we found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis may be a promising strategy for overcoming ferroptosis resistance in cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are used in the majority of patients with hypertension. However, the mechanisms of action of these drugs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism involving STIM1. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanism of action of LCCBs and may lead to the development of new drugs for treating hypertension. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but that the decline of older forests accelerated. This is partly due to the loss of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP was designed to take time to reverse the decline of older forests, but this has not yet happened. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will require a balance between the goals of the NWFP and the need to adapt to climate change.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We show that the design of acylide antibiotics can be achieved by a combination of computational and experimental methods. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

We introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. In contrast, bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania exhibit 187Os/188Os ratios <<1.0 and at face value suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os with 187Os/188Os of ∼0.13. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to the development of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be exacerbated by other diseases. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its function in the development of autoimmunity is not the same in different models.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We reconstructed the phylogeny of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a comprehensive dataset of genes and genomes. We found that the evolution of beetles and angiosperms was linked, and that the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes was key to the Mesozoic diversification of beetles. We propose that these enzymes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of beetles and their impact on the evolution of plants and the environment.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of less effective vaccines and therapies. The development of new antibody drugs is a promising strategy to combat the variants. However, the development of new antibodies is time-consuming and expensive. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of existing antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. This approach can potentially be used to develop new antibody drugs to combat the variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly phagocytic. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of C1q, a protein that may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of APOE in AD risk and suggest a possible therapeutic target for AD.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use are less well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s response to the stimulation of dopamine (DA) is blunted in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings have implications for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. The brain’s language system is not a simple “language processor” but is instead a highly integrated system that is shaped by the nature of the data it processes. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks are also the most accurate at predicting neural responses to language in the human brain. These results provide computational evidence that the language system in the human brain is shaped by the predictive structure of the data it processes.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is not clear how to use DL in scientific computing, where the problems are often ill-conditioned. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of neural networks with great approximation qualities, but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a neural network. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which neural networks with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a foundation for the use of neural networks in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. In this paper, we argue that the failure of the public to comply with public health measures is also due to a failure of science communication. We present a classic experiment that shows that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We show that this is due to the experiment’s design, which was flawed from the start. We conclude that the experiment should not be used as a case study of the failure of science communication.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for different forms of the disease. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We found that M. lepromatosis is closely related to the MRCA of the two bacteria, and that it has retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system. This suggests that M. lepromatosis is a potential pathogen of the nervous system, and that it may be responsible for some cases of leprosy that have not been attributed to M. leprae.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two main quantities that are used to quantify the state of a quantum system. However, they are not the same. In particular, the entanglement of a system is not necessarily equal to the entropy of the reduced density matrix of the system. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics of a system is intimately related to the entropy dynamics of the reduced density matrix of the system. We provide a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most general limit that can be studied analytically. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and there is a need for a vaccine that can be used in mass vaccination programs. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but it grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is protective in hamsters, and it has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. This is a major advance in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with the Black Death (1347–1353) being one of the deadliest events in human history. Today, plague is almost exclusively spread by the fleas that live on the rodent reservoir. However, it is unclear whether plague was spread by rats or by humans. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by humans, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of plague in the future.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important and least understood aspects of animal evolution. The brain is the most complex organ in the body and is responsible for all the complex behaviors that make animals the most successful organisms on Earth. The brain is also the most expensive organ to build, and thus it is important to understand how the brain has evolved to increase its capacity to process information. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is not a continuous process but rather a series of discrete shifts. These shifts are associated with the evolution of new types of neurons and the evolution of new types of connections between neurons. These shifts are important for understanding the evolution of the brain and the evolution of animal intelligence.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is the network of filaments that organizes the shape of cells. Actin filaments are also the main components of many cellular processes, such as cell migration. Actin filaments are dynamic, and they can change their length and shape. In order to change their shape, they need to be able to change their length. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is able to change the length of actin filaments. However, it is also able to change their shape. We show that this ability is critical for the function of ADF.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that the ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the population. Finally, we find that the genetic structure is not only a consequence of the admixture but also of the geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a nonrandom way. This is important to understand the history of Madagascar and to explain the unique features of the island.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. This work shows that emotional contagion occurs in a large social network, Facebook, and that it is not limited to in-person interaction. This work also suggests that people use Facebook to experience the positive emotions of others, and that observing others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, and for the study of the spread of emotions in society.

In this work, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can have a profound effect on the rate of protein synthesis. The feeling that one’s life is meaningful and worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the drivers of this pattern remain unclear. Here, we use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment itself.

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study provides insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of a human pathogen and may have implications for the development of vaccines and therapeutics for the common cold.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This sensing mechanism is essential for the regulation of the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The type IV pili are also used for twitching motility, which is essential for the colonization of the host. These findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for motility, but also as a sensor for surface attachment. This is a unique mechanism that allows bacteria to sense the presence of surfaces on short timescales, and to regulate their pathogenicity. This is important for understanding the complex interactions between bacteria and their host. It is also important for developing new strategies to combat bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the quality of global water resources.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been documented in many animal species, including free-living animals. However, the potential for these animals to act as reservoirs for SARS-CoV-2 is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to prevent future outbreaks in animals and humans. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of hydropower dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein, which are toxic to neurons. Here, we show that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is associated with the production of a variety of proinflammatory molecules, which are released into the extracellular space. These molecules are capable of activating microglia, which are the brain’s immune cells, and may contribute to the initiation of AD. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for many proteins. The folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, was studied by a combination of methods that provide high structural resolution. The results indicate that the folding of the large protein is not a simple process. The folding pathway is not known for many proteins.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps. In this study, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by disulfide stress, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli, and that it prefers to remove capped RNAs over their capped counterparts. This is the first time that a bacterial decapping enzyme has been shown to preferentially remove capped RNAs. The unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study reveals a mechanism for the removal of capped RNAs that could be important for the rapid reprogramming of gene expression during stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although the immune system is activated in response to the infection, it also becomes dysfunctional, leading to the development of a proinflammatory state. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We found that citrulline, a dietary amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of citrulline in the treatment of other inflammatory conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all the organisms that inhabit the planet. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Thus, we provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and quantum computing. However, it is brittle and easily damaged by external forces. Here, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap fully vanishes. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap is restored, by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the role of the immune system in the defense against bacteria is less clear. Here, we show that a plant immune-related peptide, NCR044, is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of this peptide is unique and different from the known mode of action of other known fungicides. This work provides a better understanding of the role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens. It also paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a fundamental unit of evolution, and the process of sperm–female interactions is critical to reproductive success. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–female interactions and the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The results are also relevant for understanding the role of force in other biological systems. The results are also relevant for understanding the role of force in other biological systems.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, has been difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, including 45,000 unique viruses. We find that the human virome is associated with a wide range of diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases. This resource will allow for the study of the human virome in the future.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI process. The results show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased the cloud droplet number concentration and decreased the cloud droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for more than a century. The most widely accepted estimate of the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean, the period of time when life first emerged, is 80 °C. However, this estimate is based on a combination of methods that have been subject to question. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the Earth decreased over geological time. This finding is consistent with previous estimates based on isotopic evidence and provides new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. C-type inactivation in BK channels is closed state-dependent and its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel gating and may lead to the development of new drugs. (Show more)

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a complex process that requires the parasite to overcome a number of physical barriers. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is the first time that we have been able to show that the parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, and it is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process. This finding has implications for the development of new strategies for the treatment and control of malaria.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is used in a variety of applications, including in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal, which has a low bandgap, by applying strain. This opens up new possibilities for the design of diamond-based devices. We also show that diamond can be transformed back into a diamond, which has a wide bandgap, by removing the strain. This can be used to control the properties of diamond, and to create a diamond that is tailored to the specific application. This work provides a fundamental understanding of the properties of diamond, and opens up new opportunities for the design and application of diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. We show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. This may have important implications for the development of strategies to combat seasonal influenza epidemics. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be important for understanding the neural basis of language acquisition and language disorders. Future studies should investigate whether the merge operation is also present in the activity of other language-related brain areas.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in the development of the nervous system and the formation of the immune system. Axin is a protein that is involved in the regulation of the Wnt signaling pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, which may be important for tissue-specific regulation.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the LH (LH GABA) promotes eating in sated animals. We also show that this system is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. This system may contribute to the development of obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the functioning of the world’s ecosystems. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is limited by the need for the bacteria to be in contact with the plant roots to fix nitrogen. Here, we demonstrate the development of a system in which the plant can control the presence or absence of nitrogen fixation in the associated bacterium. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to develop a sustainable source of nitrogen for cereal crops. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an auditory organ that is not part of its body. The spider’s web is a hyperacute acoustic antenna that is able to detect the motion of the air particles caused by sound. The spider can remotely sense the direction and location of the sound source, and it can also adjust and regenerate the web to suit its needs. This study provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of hearing in animals. It also provides a model system for studying the sensing of fluid motion and the regeneration of the auditory organ. It is expected to be useful for the development of new acoustic sensors and devices. (Show more)

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming. The warming from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern has raised concerns about the efficacy of current vaccines. Here we report the design of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is more manufacturable, immunogenic, and cross-reactive than the RBD used in current vaccines. This engineered RBD can be expressed on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD may be a promising candidate for a future vaccine. This engineered RBD may also be useful for the development of diagnostics and therapeutics.

The role of the ALK receptor in development is well established. However, the ligand(s) that activate ALK in vivo are not known. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like (DrALK) are ligands for zebrafish ALKALs. We further show that DrALKs are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish lateral line. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/ALKals in neural crest development. This is of importance for the understanding of the role of ALK in human cancer. Furthermore, our results suggest that the ALKALs are evolutionarily conserved in their function.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the most devastating outbreaks in human history. The earliest genomes of Y. pestis are from the Neolithic period, and the number of genomes available to date is too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 genomes from the Bronze Age, which increases the number of genomes available to explore the diversity of the pathogen during this period. We find that the pathogen was nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct, and that it rapidly spread across continents throughout this period. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague. Future research should focus on the role of fleas in the pathogen’s evolution and dispersal. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 2016 and 2020 Republican presidential candidate. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of HM.

The conversion of native grasslands to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems to mitigate these losses remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC in the more stable mineral-associated fraction. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and support food production. This study also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems. This work provides a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems that can be applied to other regions and soil types. (Show more)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a valuable resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators is nectar, which is produced by specialized glands in the flower. Nectar is a sugary fluid that is often colored, and this color is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of this trait in Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species. This work provides insight into the evolution of nectar color and the role of alkaloids in this process. It also identifies a convergent trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work contributes to our understanding of the evolution of pollination systems and the role of alkaloids in this process. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women from Bavaria in southern Germany, who are known to have been deformed by cranial deformation. We show that the genetic ancestry of these women is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This is particularly striking in women with artificial skull deformations, who also differ in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of a periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a larger national outbreak. We also identified a number of pathogens that were previously underappreciated, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, which is endemic in the region. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using mNGS to investigate the pathogen landscape of a resource-scarce setting and the potential for coordinated pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to better understand the pathogen landscape in other resource-limited settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand synthesis. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the mechanism of lagging strand synthesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of the genetic code, nucleic acids were the primary information carriers. In the laboratory, it is possible to create RNA-based life, but only in the absence of proteins. Here, we show that it is possible to create RNA-based life with proteins, and that the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study can provide a reference for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a number of mechanisms to maintain copper at levels that are neither toxic nor limiting. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) is one of these mechanisms. We show that the xan BGC isocyanide products bind copper and that the presence of copper impacts the intracellular copper content of A. fumigatus. We also show that xan BGC isocyanide products have antimicrobial properties and that copper is required for this activity. These results suggest that the xan BGC is a source of fungal natural products that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. This is the first report of a fungal natural product that binds copper. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the interactions of fungi with other microbes. (Read more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a drill sample of laminated mudstone (Buckskin) at Marias Pass in Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is the first detection of this polymorph in a sedimentary rock. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the sediment suggests that the sediment was sourced from the crater wall/rim/central peak. The amorphous silica, magnetite, and mixed-cation salts and oxides are diagenesis products derived from multiple aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The diagenesis products are consistent with the sedimentary environment of “Lake Gale” and the sediment source region.

Frost events are a major threat to plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere, but the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly linked to the evolutionary history of the species. We also show that the resistance strategies of species are not fixed, but can be modified by natural selection. Our findings can be used to inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of these cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is not clear. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These cells are dependent on the transcription factors T-bet and Stat4, and their development requires the expression of both the IL-12 and the IL-6 pathways. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This dual mechanism of action may be important in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (truncated)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. Importantly, we find that motor neurons are not the only target of astrocytes from ALS patients. This suggests that the disease process is not restricted to motor neurons and that the disease is multifactorial. This method will enable the study of the disease in a much larger cohort of patients and will facilitate the development of new therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now show that Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma phagocytophilum to colonize the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vectors and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in vertebrate evolution. The short tail of birds is a key adaptation for flight, but the origin of the short tail is poorly understood. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians. This new taxon, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the short tail. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of pigments, such as carotenoids, that are not present in other vertebrates. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) is determined by the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is not present in these animals. We also show that this mechanism of color determination evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the color of anurans and suggest a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a model for the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells are characterized by the ability to form tumorigenic cells, which are referred to as cancer stem cells (CSCs). CSCs are thought to be responsible for the recurrence and metastasis of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG, which is a marker of CSCs. This study provides a mechanism by which hypoxia induces the expression of NANOG, which is a marker of CSCs. This may be a target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides a mechanism by which ALKBH5 may be used as a therapeutic target in cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a method to determine the animal origin of parchment. We show that the source of the parchment in the first pocket Bibles is not fetal, as has been suggested, but instead is from the skins of maturing animals of several species. This method is noninvasive and can be applied to a large number of samples. It is a significant advance in the study of the earliest parchment codices.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. The age of the extinction is also critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model presented here is based on a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike glycoprotein from the first isolate of SARS-CoV-2 (G614) with the most common variant (D614). We find that the G614 spike is more open and that this may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent conformational changes required for membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the development of future variants of the vaccine and therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) to the case of Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is also a step towards the solution of a long-standing open problem in the theory of repeated games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.
